text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with sausage and sweet corn muffins
that's right all these years you've been
eating corn muffins without meat like
some kind of hapless vegan but don't
feel bad you're still relatively young
so with the help of this video hopefully
you can make up for some lost time and
by the way before we get started I will
admit this was an experiment which
usually means there are things I would
change if I made it again but besides
probably using the wrong kind of sausage
this really did come out quite well but
anyway we'll talk more about that later
but for now let's go ahead get started
by cooking the aforementioned possibly
wrong kind of sausage so in a pan set
over medium-high heat with a little bit
of olive oil in it I'm going to add some
spicy Italian sausage which for me was
too large links that I removed from the
casing and all we need to do here is
cook this while we break it up with a
spatula and we'll keep doing that until
two things happen we've broken that
sausage up into some nice small crumbles
and it's pretty much cooked through
which is basically what I had right here
and at that point we'll stop and add
some diced red bell pepper and we'll mix
that in and then we'll cook that for
about two minutes just to sort of take
the raw edge off and of course just
because I'm using sweet bell peppers
doesn't mean you can't use hot peppers
you are after all the mclovin of how to
be stuffing your muffin so if I wasn't
using a spicy sausage I might go with a
hot pepper here but anyway like I said
we'll cook that for a couple minutes
just to soften and sweeten those peppers
a bit and at that point we can turn off
the key because this step is pretty much
done except for one optional but
recommended step you're probably going
to have a good amount of rendered fat in
the pan which you may want to drain and
as you know how I usually like to do it
is with a paper towel and use that to
sort of wick and blot up that grease
which I think works pretty good and you
don't have to get a strainer all greasy
so you go ahead and remove as much fat
as you want which could be all of it
but as you know fat is flavor so I might
suck up a little more but I ended up
leaving about a tablespoon and then all
we need to do is set that aside and let
it cool while we move on to the dry
ingredients so in a mixing bowl we'll
start with some white all-purpose flour
as well as an equal amount of cornmeal
and then we're also going to need a
little touch of baking soda
no not baking powder don't get confused
baking soda and then usually we'd add a
little bit of cayenne here but because
we're using such a spicy sausage we'd
need any so let's add a little anyway
and then we'll grab a whisk and give
that a thorough mixing to combine those
ingredients
since nobody sips anymore I mean maybe
your grandma does but most people don't
so we will give that a mix and set that
aside while we move on to the wet
ingredients and there's just two we are
going to do a couple large eggs to which
we will add some buttermilk and then as
soon as we take a whisk and give that a
mix we'll move on to final production
which is basically just combining
everything together so let's pour our
wet ingredients into our bowl of dry you
know the old saying always add wet to
dry and vice versa and then besides our
wet and dry ingredients we're also going
to want some chopped green onions as
well as a little bit of sharp cheddar
cheese which by the way I graded myself
by hand mostly because I'm not a huge
fan of cellulose coated food and then of
course because we're making fresh corn
muffins we need some fresh corn so I'm
going to toss in one cup of very sweet
white corn kernels and then by now our
sausage mixture should be room temp so
we'll add that and then last but not
least we will finish our batter with
butter
so let's pour in a quarter cup of melted
butter and we'll grab a spatula and give
this a mix and generally with this kind
of thing people are terrified about over
mixing you over mixing but here you can
relax we're stuffing this corn muffin
with so many goodies it's going to be
tender and delicious no matter how long
you mix it but having said that why mix
something longer than you have to so all
we want to do is keep mixing and
stirring and kind of folding until the
flour disappears so that's looking just
about perfect right there at that point
we'll stop and move on to making muffins
and for that of course you're going to
need a muffin pan which as you can see
has been lined with these parchment
muffin cups and by the way please try to
find these natural colored ones
I hate those pink yellow and blue ones
so please don't use them but anyway once
our pan is line we'll go ahead and
transfer that batter in using a spoon or
maybe an ice cream scoop like I'm doing
here which I find is easiest at least
messy way and then once we successfully
transfer that batter evenly into those
12 cups our muffins are pretty much
ready for the oven except I do like to
top it with a little more shredded
cheddar and not too much just a few
shreds here in the
and then once that set we can go ahead
and transfer this into the center of a
375 degree oven for about 25 to 30
minutes or until they're a beautiful
golden brown and look something like
this
check it out those look pretty good if I
had to guess I'd say they were done but
there's no money in guessing so we will
want to test this with a bamboo skier or
toothpick and if you stick that in it
should come out clean if you pull that
out and see some raw batter on it you'll
need to put your muffins back in for a
few minutes but that's okay that's just
you cooking and then assuming they have
cooked long enough we do want to let
these cool down a little before we try
to eat them okay at least a few minutes
personally I think something like this
is much better warm than it is piping
hot so I did let mine cool down to just
barely warm before going in for the
official taste which I was very excited
for because he's looked so gorgeous but
if I'm being completely honest they were
not amazing I mean they could have been
amazing but I used the wrong sausage
that spicy intensely flavored Italian
sausage was just too strong for the rest
of the ingredients I'm thinking this
would have been better with something
mild like a breakfast sausage which has
those warmer sweeter spices which i
think would have worked better with the
corn so while look orgeous and the
texture was very nice my choice of spicy
Italian sausage did not elevate this to
where it should have been so was I
discouraged no not at all in fact the
opposite I really do think of these were
done with a milder sweeter sausage they
would make an incredible brunch or
breakfast treat maybe even split and
toasted and topped with poached eggs oh
yeah that's an idea but anyway that's it
what I'm calling sausage and sweet corn
muffins this turned out to be one of
those rare recipes that was both a
catastrophic failure and a stunning
success so I really do hope you give
this a try soon head over to food wishes
comm for all the ingredient amounts and
more info as usual
and as always enjoy
